{{Mitt Romney series}} The '''business career of Mitt Romney''' began shortly after he finished graduate school in 1975. At that time, [[Mitt Romney|Romney]] entered the [[management consulting]] industry, and in 1977 secured a position at [[Bain & Company]]. Later serving as its chief executive officer, he helped bring the company out of financial crisis<!-- this is supported by detailed sources in body of article -->. In 1984, he co-founded and led the spin-off [[Bain Capital]], a [[private equity]] investment firm that became highly profitable and one of the [[List of private equity firms#Largest private equity firms|largest such firms]] in the nation<!-- this is supported by detailed sources in body of article -->. The fortune he earned from his business career is estimated at $190–250 million.
==Entry into management consulting at Boston Consulting Group: 1975–1977== [[Image:The Boston Consulting Group logo.png|thumb|right|400px|Logo of Boston Consulting Group]]After he received a [[JD/MBA|joint]] [[Juris Doctor]] and [[Master of Business Administration]] from [[Harvard University]] in 1975, Mitt Romney was recruited by several firms and chose to remain in Massachusetts to work for [[Boston Consulting Group]] (BCG), reasoning that working as a [[management consultant]] to a variety of companies would better prepare him for a future position as a chief executive.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="MrPowerPoint"/><ref>Michael Kranish, Scott Helman ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZP3-rXn0H8sC&pg=PT221 The Real Romney]'', page 97 (HarperCollins 2012).</ref> He was part of a 1970s wave of top graduates who chose to go into consulting rather than join a major company directly.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/11/sunday-review/consultant-nation.html | title=Consultant Nation | author=[[David Leonhardt|Leonhardt, David]] | newspaper=The New York Times | date=December 11, 2011}}</ref>
Romney had his pick of jobs at the nation’s biggest and most prestigious consulting firms, and at that time BCG was neither. Its idiosyncratic founder, [[Bruce Henderson]], was regarded as outside the mainstream of corporate consulting, and BCG was routinely disparaged by faculty and students at Harvard Business School.<ref name=Barbaro /> But BCG was a pioneering upstart that fostered camaraderie among its employees, who traveled around the country to advise clients, and that is where Mitt Romney chose to start his career.<ref name=Barbaro>Michael Barbaro. [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/08/us/politics/mitt-romney-and-benjamin-netanyahu-are-old-friends.html?pagewanted=all "A Friendship Dating to 1976 Resonates in 2012"], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (April 7, 2012).</ref> His legal and business education proved useful in his job<ref name="bgseries3"/> while he applied BCG principles such as the [[growth-share matrix]], which is a simple chart to assist large corporations in deciding how to allocate cash among their business units.<ref name="nykr2007">{{cite news | url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2007/10/29/071029fa_fact_lizza?currentPage=all | title=The Mission: Mitt Romney's strategies for success | author=Lizza, Ryan | magazine=[[The New Yorker]] | date=October 29, 2007 | authorlink=Ryan Lizza}}</ref> He was viewed as having a bright future there.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name=Barbaro /> Romney worked nights and weekends, and traveled frequently in the U.S. and to Europe on business.<ref>Sacha Pfieffer. [http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2007/06/26/romneys_harvard_classmates_recall_his_quick_mind_positive_attitude/?page=full "Romney's Harvard classmates recall his quick mind, positive attitude"], ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' (June 26, 2007).</ref>
==Management consulting at Bain & Company: 1977–1984== [[File:Horizontal RED LG DIGITAL.png|left|thumb|246x246px|Logo of Bain & Company]] In 1977, he was hired by [[Bain & Company]], a management consulting firm in Boston that had been formed a few years earlier by [[Bill Bain (consultant)|Bill Bain]] and other former BCG employees.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="nykr2007"/><ref name="hewitt-48">Hugh Hewitt. ''A Mormon in the White House?: 10 Things Every Conservative Should Know About Mitt Romney'', pp. 48–49 (Regnery Publishing 2007).</ref> Bain would later say of the thirty-year-old Romney, "He had the appearance of confidence of a guy who was maybe ten years older."<ref name="howmakemoney">{{Cite news|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick|title=Romney's Fortunes Tied to Business Riches |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/04/us/politics/04bain.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 4, 2007 }}</ref> Unlike other consulting firms, which issued recommendations and then left, Bain & Company had a practice<!-- "Bain way" -->, that Romney learned, of immersing itself in a client's business and working with them until changes were implemented.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="nykr2007"/>
Geoffrey Rehnert, who also worked at Bain & Company, <ref>[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=85675&privcapId=95501&previousCapId=23613781&previousTitle=Kraft%20Group,%20LLC "Geoffrey S. Rehnert J.D."], Bloomberg Businessweek (Accessed August 29, 2012).</ref> recalls that those who gravitated to Bain were mostly not from wealthy backgrounds.<ref name="nym-onep" /> The company operated as a results-oriented [[meritocracy]], and Romney excelled there.<ref name="hewitt-48" /> He became a vice-president of the firm in 1978,<ref name="crim102194">{{Cite news| url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1994/10/21/romney-gains-momentum-as-he-keeps/ | title=Romney Gains Momentum As He Keeps On Running | author=Gell, Jeffrey N. | newspaper=[[The Harvard Crimson]] | date=October 21, 1994}}</ref> and worked with clients such as the [[Monsanto Company]], [[Outboard Marine Corporation]], [[Burlington Industries]], and [[Corning Incorporated]].<ref name="MrPowerPoint"/> Within a few years, he was considered one of their best consultants and at times sought by clients over more senior partners.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="vf-excerpt"/>
Romney aspired to start a new business, and in 1983, Bill Bain offered him the chance to head a new venture that would buy into companies, have them benefit from Bain consulting techniques, and allow the venture's partners to reap higher rewards than consulting fees.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="nykr2007"/> He initially refrained from accepting the offer, and Bain re-arranged the terms in a complicated partnership structure so that there was no financial or professional risk to Romney.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="howmakemoney"/><ref name="nyt060407db"/> Thus, in 1984, Romney left Bain & Company to co-found the spin-off [[private equity]] investment firm, [[Bain Capital]].<ref name="atl-pappu">{{Cite news| author=Pappu, Sridhar | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200509/pappu/3 | title=The Holy Cow! Candidate | magazine=[[The Atlantic Monthly]] | date=September 2005}}</ref>
==Private equity at Bain Capital: 1984–1990== [[File:Bain Capital.png|thumb|right|246px|alt=Plain logo consisting of white serif letters against dark blue background|Logo of Bain Capital]]Bain Capital was founded in 1984 by [[Bain & Company]] partners Mitt Romney, T. Coleman Andrews III, and [[Eric Kriss]].<ref name="atl-pappu"/> In addition to the three founding partners, the early team included Geoffrey S. Rehnert and others from Bain & Company.<ref name=bain_fundinguniverse>[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Bain-amp;-Company-Company-History.html Bain & Company Profile]. Funding Universe, 2000</ref> Romney initially had the titles of president<ref name="bg-leave1">{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8199011.html | title=Bain & Co. plans major layoffs, Boston staff hardest hit | first=Gordon | last=McKibben | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=October 30, 1990}}{{subscription required}}</ref> and managing general partner (or managing partner).<ref name="bg-leave1b">{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-7645576.html | title=Bain agrees to reshape ownership | first=Diane E. | last=Lewis | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=January 30, 1991}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref name="nyt-leave1">{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/business/business-people-bain-names-chief-executive-and-begins-a-reorganization.html | title=Bain Names Chief Executive And Begins a Reorganization | author=Fabrikant, Geraldine | newspaper=The New York Times | date=January 30, 1991}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-11836430.html | title=Venture capital primer | first=Alan S. | last=Horowitz | magazine=[[Utah Business]] | date=February 1, 1992}}</ref> He later was referred to as managing director<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8473315.html | title=Dad's ideas live on – and in others | first=Mitt | last=Romney | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=June 21, 1998}}</ref> or CEO<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8329806.html | title=They're trying to sell volunteerism up the river | first=David | last=Nyhan | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=May 28, 1995}}{{subscription required}}</ref> as well. He was also the sole shareholder of the firm.<ref>Romney, ''Turnaround'', pp. 15–16.</ref> At the beginning, the firm had fewer than ten employees.<ref name="blum"/> When new employees were hired, they were generally in their twenties and top-ranked graduates from [[Stanford University]] or [[Harvard University]], both of which Romney had attended.<ref>Michael Kranish, Scott Helman ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZP3-rXn0H8sC&pg=PT221 The Real Romney]'', page 134 (HarperCollins 2012).</ref>
In the face of skepticism from potential investors, Romney and his partners spent a year raising the $37 million in funds needed to start the new operation.<ref name="MrPowerPoint">{{Cite news | author=Rees, Matthew | url=http://www.american.com/archive/2006/december/mitt-romney/ | title=Mister PowerPoint Goes to Washington | magazine=[[The American (magazine)|The American]] | date=December 1, 2006 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130094507/http://www.american.com/archive/2006/december/mitt-romney/ | archivedate=January 30, 2012 | df= }}</ref><ref name="howmakemoney"/><ref name="nym-onep">{{cite news | url=http://nymag.com/print/?/news/politics/mitt-romney-2011-10/ | title=Mitt Romney and the 1% Economy | author=Wallace-Wells, Benjamin | magazine=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] | date=October 23, 2011}}</ref><ref name="blum">{{Cite news| last = Blum | first = Justin | first2 = Lisa | last2=Lerer | title = Romney's Record Defies Image as Job-Creator| publisher = [[Bloomberg News]]| date = July 20, 2011| url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-20/romney-as-job-creator-clashes-with-bain-record-of-job-cuts.html}}</ref> Early investors also included members of elite Salvadoran families who fled the country's [[Salvadoran Civil War|civil war]].<ref>{{cite news | first = Justin | last = Elliot | title = The roots of Bain Capital in El Salvador’s civil war | date = January 20, 2012 | url = http://www.salon.com/2012/01/20/the_roots_of_bain_capital_in_el_salvador/ | work = [[Salon (website)|Salon]] | accessdate = July 21, 2012}}</ref> They and other wealthy Latin Americans invested $9 million primarily through [[Offshore company|offshore companies]] registered in [[Panama]].<ref>{{cite news | first = Joseph | last = Tanfani |author2=Melanie Mason |author3=Matea Gold | title = Bain Capital started with help of offshore investors | date = July 19, 2012 | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-bain-creation-20120719,0,5698366,full.story | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | accessdate = July 21, 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Staples Savi Ranch.jpg|thumb|left|x200px|Staples store in [[Yorba Linda, California|Yorba Linda, CA]]]]While Bain Capital was founded by Bain executives, the firm was not an affiliate or a division of Bain & Company but rather a completely separate company. Initially, the two firms shared the same offices – in an office tower at [[Copley Place]] in Boston<ref>Michael Kranish, Scott Helman ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZP3-rXn0H8sC&pg=PT221 The Real Romney]'', page 133 (HarperCollins 2012).</ref> – and a similar approach to improving business operations. However, the two firms had put in place certain protections to avoid sharing information between the two companies and the Bain & Company executives had the ability to veto investments that posed potential conflicts of interest.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/22/business/big-consultants-woo-employees-by-offering-a-piece-of-the-action.html Big Consultants Woo Employees by Offering a Piece of the Action]. New York Times, October 22, 1999</ref> Bain Capital also provided an investment opportunity for partners of Bain & Company. Bain Capital's original $37 million fund was raised entirely from private individuals in mid-1984.<ref name=bain_fundinguniverse /> The firm initially gave a cut of its profits to Bain & Company, but Romney later persuaded Bill Bain to give that up.<ref name="nyt060407db">{{Cite news| url=http://dealbook.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/06/04/romneys-presidential-run-throws-spotlight-on-bain-capital/ | title=Romney's Presidential Run Puts Spotlight on Bain Capital | author=Sorkin, Andrew Ross | newspaper=The New York Times | date=June 4, 2007 | authorlink=Andrew Ross Sorkin}}</ref>
The Bain Capital team was initially reluctant to invest its capital. By 1985, things were going poorly enough that Romney considered closing the operation, returning investors' money back to them, and having the partners go back to their old positions.<ref>Michael Kranish, Scott Helman ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZP3-rXn0H8sC&pg=PT221 The Real Romney]'', page 138 (HarperCollins 2012).</ref> The partners saw weak spots in so many potential deals that by 1986, very few had been done.<ref name="bgseries3">{{Cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/2008/specials/romney/articles/part3_main/ | title=The Making of Mitt Romney: Part 3: Reaping profit in study, sweat | author=Gavin, Robert | author2=Pfeiffer, Sacha | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=June 26, 2007}}</ref> At first, Bain Capital focused on [[venture capital]] opportunities.<ref name="bgseries3"/> One of Bain's earliest and most notable venture investments was in [[Staples, Inc.]], the [[office supply]] [[retailer]]. In 1986, Bain provided $4.5 million to two supermarket executives, Leo Kahn and [[Thomas G. Stemberg]], to open an office supply supermarket in [[Brighton, Massachusetts]].<ref>"Growth in Office-Supply 'Supermarkets' Threatens Tough War for Market Share". Wall Street Journal, December 1, 1988</ref> The fast-growing retail chain went public in 1989;<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8113146.html Staples Inc. Plans to Go Public]. The Boston Globe, March 22, 1989</ref> by 1996, the company had grown to over 1,100 stores,<ref>[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Staples-Inc-Company-History.html Staples Inc. Company Profile]. Funding Universe, 2002</ref> and by 2008, over 2,000 stores.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/12/business/worldbusiness/12fobriefs-STAPLESSETSD_BRF.html | title=The Netherlands: Staples Sets Deal | agency=Bloomberg News | newspaper=The New York Times | date=June 12, 2008}}</ref> Bain Capital eventually reaped a nearly sevenfold return on its investment, and Romney sat on the Staples board of directors for over a decade.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="nym-onep"/><ref name="blum"/> Another very successful investment occurred in 1986 when $1 million was invested in medical equipment maker Calumet Coach, which eventually returned $34 million.<ref name="nyt-dade"/> A few years later, Bain Capital made an investment in the technology research outfit the [[Gartner Group]], which ended up returning a 16-fold gain.<ref name="nyt-dade"/>
Bain invested the $37 million of capital in its first fund in twenty companies and by 1989 was generating an annualized return in excess of 50 percent. By the end of the decade, Bain's second fund, raised in 1987 had deployed $106 million into 13 investments.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/24/magazine/counselor-to-the-king.html Counselor To The King]. New York Times, September 24, 1989</ref> As the firm began organizing around funds, each such fund was run by a specific general partnership – that included all Bain Capital executives as well as others – which in turn was controlled by Bain Capital Inc., the management company that Romney had full ownership control of.<ref name="nyt-whenback">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/16/us/politics/when-did-romney-step-back-from-bain-its-complicated.htm?_r=1 | title= When Did Romney Step Back From Bain? It's Complicated, Filings Suggest | author=Confessore, Nicholas | author2=Shear, Michael D. | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=July 16, 2012 | page=A10}}</ref> As CEO, Romney had the final approval say on every deal made.<ref name="bg-reins"/>
In 1987, former [[Herman's World of Sporting Goods]] CEO Jack Smith made a pitch to Romney, and Bain joined several other backers to help Smith open nine sporting-goods mega stores. Kmart bought the [[Sports Authority]] chain for $75 million.<ref name=Notte />
[[File:Sports Authority in Concord.JPG|thumb|right|Sports Authority store in [[Concord, California|Concord, CA]]]]Romney discovered few investment opportunities himself (and those that he did, often failed to make money for the firm).<ref name="real-155"/> Instead, he focused on analyzing the merits of possible deals that others brought forward and on recruiting investors to participate in them once approved.<ref name="real-155">Michael Kranish, Scott Helman ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZP3-rXn0H8sC&pg=PT221 The Real Romney]'', pp. 141 and 145 (HarperCollins 2012).</ref> The firm initially gave a cut of its profits to Bain & Company, but Romney persuaded Bain to give that up.<ref name="nyt060407db"/> Within Bain Capital, Romney spread profits from deals widely within the firm to keep people motivated, often keeping less than ten percent for himself.<ref name="nyt-depagr"/> Viewed as a fair manager, he received considerable loyalty from the firm's members.<ref name="nym-onep"/> Romney's wary instincts were still in force at times, and he was generally data-driven and averse to risk.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="nym-onep"/>
He wanted to drop a Bain Capital [[hedge fund]] that initially lost money, but other partners prevailed and it eventually gained billions.<ref name="bgseries3"/> Romney was on the board of directors of Damon Corporation, a medical testing company later found guilty of defrauding the government; Bain Capital tripled its investment before selling off the company, and the fraud was discovered by the new owners (Romney was never implicated).<ref name="bgseries3"/> In some cases, Romney had little involvement with a company once acquired.<ref name="blum"/> Beginning in 1989, the firm, which began as a [[venture capital]] source investing in [[start-up companies]], adjusted its strategy to focus on [[leveraged buyout]]s and [[growth capital]] investments in more mature companies.<ref>"Venture-Capital Funds Grow Larger and Larger – But Start-Up Companies Find They're Still Left Out in the Cold". The Wall Street Journal, September 7, 1989</ref> Their model was to buy existing firms with money mostly borrowed against their assets, partner with existing management to apply Bain methodology to their operations (rather than the hostile takeovers practiced in other leverage buyout scenarios), and sell them off in a few years.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="howmakemoney"/> Existing CEOs were offered large equity stakes in the process, owing to Bain Capital's belief in the emerging [[agency theory]] that CEOs should be bound to maximizing [[shareholder value]] rather than other goals.<ref name="nym-onep"/> By the end of 1990, Bain had raised $175 million of capital and financed 35 companies with combined revenues of $3.5 billion.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/business/business-people-bain-names-chief-executive-and-begins-a-reorganization.html Bain Names Chief Executive And Begins a Reorganization]. New York Times, January 30, 1991</ref>
==Temporary return to Bain & Company: 1991–1992== In 1990, Romney was asked to return to Bain & Company, which was facing financial collapse.<ref name="atl-pappu"/> He was announced as its new CEO in January 1991<ref name="bg-leave1b"/><ref name="nyt-leave1"/> but drew only a symbolic [[One-dollar salary|salary of one dollar]]<ref name="atl-pappu"/> (he remained managing general partner of Bain Capital during this time).<ref name="bg-leave1b"/><ref name="nyt-leave1"/> His turnaround of Bain & Company has been identified as a primary example of Romney's turnaround talents from the business world, and Romney says there was no upside for him personally: "There was no particular reason to do it other than a sense of obligation and duty to an organization that had done great things for me and which employed a thousand people."<ref name=things>Hugh Hewitt. ''A Mormon in the White House?: 10 Things Every Conservative Should Know About Mitt Romney'', pp. 48–58 (Regnery Publishing 2007).</ref> However, once Romney took up the challenge, his stake in success became enormous, and his reputation would have been diminished if Bain & Company went bankrupt.<ref name="rollingstone.com" /> He proceeded to apply the "Bain way" to Bain & Company itself.<ref name=things />
Bringing along two lieutenants from Bain Capital, Romney began a traveling campaign to rally employees at all Bain offices globally. Romney also negotiated a complex settlement between the Bain partnership and the firm's lenders, including a $10 million reduction in the $38 million Bain owed the Bank of New England,<ref>{{cite news |last=Schoenberg |first=Shira |title=Romney accused of getting a ‘bailout’ |url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-07-15/news/29778328_1_mitt-romney-loan-forgiveness-federal-bailout |newspaper=Boston Globe |date=July 15, 2011 |accessdate=2012-01-30}}</ref> which by that time had been seized by the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation|FDIC]] and placed in [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7]] liquidation. Romney was able to negotiate this reduction in the debt amount with the FDIC by warning that he would use the remaining cash that Bain & Company had on hand as bonuses for Bain executives, starting with VPs making $200,000 and up.<ref name="rollingstone.com">{{cite web |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/the-federal-bailout-that-saved-mitt-romney-20120829?page=2 |title= The Federal Bailout That Saved Mitt Romney |publisher=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]] |author=Tim Dickinson |date=August 29, 2012 |accessdate=2012-08-29}}</ref> This was a costly deal for the FDIC, but Romney's brinksmanship worked, at no expense to taxpayers.<ref name=rollingstone.com /><ref>Kessler, Glenn. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/post/bidens-incorrect-claim-that-a-bain-bailout-cost-american-taxpayers/2012/09/03/b349eab8-f5db-11e1-8b93-c4f4ab1c8d13_blog.html "Biden’s incorrect claim that a Bain ‘bailout’ cost American taxpayers"], [[The Washington Post]] (September 4, 2012).</ref> Romney’s plan involved "a complicated restructuring of the firm's stock-ownership plan, real-estate holdings, bank loans, and money still owed to partners".<ref name="american.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.american.com/archive/2006/december/mitt-romney/ |title=Mister Powerpoint Goes to Washington |publisher=[[The American (magazine)|The American]] |author=Matthew Rees |date=December 1, 2006 |accessdate=2012-01-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130094507/http://www.american.com/archive/2006/december/mitt-romney/ |archivedate=January 30, 2012 |df= }}</ref> To avoid the financial crisis that a buyout would have triggered, the group of founding partners agreed to return about $100M cash and forgive outstanding debt.<ref name="consultingmag.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.consultingmag.com/CMCoverFeat-Bainfeb01.html |title=Raising Bain |publisher=Consulting Magazine |author=Jack Sweeney |date=February 2001 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815191854/http://www.consultingmag.com/CMCoverFeat-Bainfeb01.html |archivedate=2007-08-15 |accessdate=2012-01-30}}</ref>
Romney also imposed a new governing structure that included Bain and the other founding partners giving up control, and increasing fiscal transparency.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="MrPowerPoint"/><ref name="atl-pappu"/> Within about a year, he had led Bain & Company through a successful turnaround and returned the firm to profitability without further layoffs or partner defections.<ref name="MrPowerPoint"/> He turned Bain & Company over to new leadership and returned to Bain Capital in December 1992.<ref name="bgseries3"/><ref name="ap022407">{{Cite news| url=http://www.telegram.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070224/NEWS/702240385/1052/RSS01 | title=Romney urges states to divest from Iran despite links to business interests there | author=Johnson, Glen | agency=Associated Press | newspaper=[[Telegram & Gazette]] | location=Worcester | date=February 24, 2007}}</ref><ref>Hugh Hewitt. ''A Mormon in the White House?: 10 Things Every Conservative Should Know About Mitt Romney'', p. 51 (Regnery Publishing 2007).</ref>
Some of the techniques that Romney employed during this temporary mission at Bain & Company were as follows: at the outset, he demanded unanimous approval from the partners at Bain & Company for his designation as CEO, and also demanded that each partner commit to staying at least a year so as to give the turnaround a fair chance. He limited partner meetings to Saturdays, so that all of the weekdays could be devoted to taking care of client business. Romney reduced the company's physical space, evaluated which partners were producing and which were not, arranged bridge financing, and focused on hiring top talent from top schools, while rescinding prior offers that were not up to standard.<ref name=things />
Although in the role for just two years before returning to Bain Capital, Romney's work had three profound impacts on the firm. First, ownership was officially shifted from the owners to the firm's 70 [[Partner (business rank)|general partners]]. Second, transparency in the firm's finances increased dramatically (e.g. partners were able to know each other's salaries<ref name="american.com" />). Third, Bill Bain relinquished ownership in the firm that carried his name. Within a year, Bain bounced back to profitability without major partner defections,<ref name="american.com" /> and the groundwork was laid for a period of steady growth.
==Back at Bain Capital for the rest of the 1990s== [[Image:Brookstone Outlet Store, Kittery ME.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A Brookstone outlet store in [[Kittery, Maine]]]]After Romney and Bain took over [[Brookstone]] in 1991, they replaced Brookstone's CEO in 1993, shifted to more Brookstone-branded items, moved more catalog content onto the company's website in 1996, and, instead of selling gifts began offering more practical items. Brookstone survived while its competitor, [[Sharper Image]], declared bankruptcy.<ref name=Notte />
In July 1992 (while Romney was still rescuing Bain & Company), Bain Capital acquired [[Ampad]] from [[Mead Corporation]], which had acquired the company in 1986. Mead, which was experiencing difficulties integrating Ampad's products into its existing product lines, generated a cash gain of $56 million on the sale.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1992/07/03/business/company-news-mead-corp-to-lay-off-1000.html Mead Corp. to Lay Off 1,000]. New York Times, July 3, 1992</ref> Under Bain's ownership, the company enjoyed a significant growth in sales from $106.7 million in 1992 to $583.9 million in 1996, when the company was listed on the [[New York Stock Exchange]]. Under Bain's ownership, the company also made a number of acquisitions, including writing products company SCM in July 1994, brand names from the American Trading and Production Corporation in August 1995, WR Acquisition and the Williamhouse-Regency Division of Delaware, Inc. in October, 1995, Niagara Envelope Company, Inc. in 1996, and Shade/Allied, Inc. in February 1997.<ref name="answers">{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/american-pad-paper-company?cat=biz-fin |title=American Pad & Paper Company Profile |publisher=Answers.com |accessdate=2012-02-11}}</ref> Ampad's revenue began to decline in 1997 and the company laid off employees and closed production facilities to maintain profitability.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.boston.com/news/daily/26/ampad.pdf |title=Ampad: A controversial deal |newspaper=The Boston Globe |author=James Abundis and Robert Gavin |accessdate=January 4, 2012}}</ref> The Ampad transaction is one of Romney's few regrets from his Bain years.<ref name=Notte>Jason Notte. [http://www.thestreet.com/story/11138475/1/5-of-mitt-romneys-best-bain-capital-buys.html "5 of Mitt Romney's Best Bain Capital Buys"], ''[[TheStreet.com]]'' (June 1, 2011).</ref>
In 1994, Bain Capital acquired [[Totes]], a producer of umbrellas and overshoes.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/28/business/company-news-totes-is-bought-by-boston-investment-firm.html Totes is Bought By Boston Investment Firm]. New York Times, June 28, 1994</ref> Three years later, Totes, under Bain’s ownership, acquired Isotoner, a producer of leather gloves.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/06/business/totes-to-buy-a-majority-interest-in-aris-isotoner.html Totes To Buy A Majority Interest In Aris Isotoner]. New York Times, June 6, 1997</ref> Totes Isotoner is now the largest supplier of umbrellas in the world.
Bain Capital, together with [[Thomas H. Lee Partners]], acquired [[Experian]], the consumer credit reporting business of TRW, in 1996 for more than $1 billion. Formerly known as TRW's Information Systems and Services unit, Experian is one of the leading providers of credit reports on consumers and businesses in the US.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/10/business/trw-credit-reporting-unit-to-be-sold-for-1-billion.html TRW Credit Reporting Unit To Be Sold for $1 Billion]. Bloomberg Business News, February 10, 1996</ref> The company was sold to [[Great Universal Stores]] for $1.7 billion just months after being acquired.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/15/business/large-british-retailer-to-buy-us-credit-data-company.html Large British Retailer to Buy U.S. Credit-Data Company]. New York Times, November 15, 1996</ref>
Other notable Bain investments of the late 1990s included [[Sealy Corporation]] (the manufacturer of mattresses),<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/04/business/company-news-sealy-to-be-sold-to-management-and-an-investor-group.html Sealy to be Sold to Management and an Investor Group]. New York Times, November 4, 1997</ref> [[Alliance Laundry Systems]],<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/24/business/company-news-raytheon-in-358-million-deal-to-sell-laundry-business.html Raytheon in $358 million Deal to Sell Laundry Business]. New York Times, February 24, 1998</ref> [[Domino's Pizza]],<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/26/business/company-news-domino-s-pizza-founder-to-retire-and-sell-a-stake.html Domino's Pizza Founder To Retire And Sell A Stake]. New York Times, September 26, 1998</ref> and Artisan Entertainment.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/21/business/media-playing-movies-like-a-growth-stock.html Playing Movies Like a Growth Stock]. New York Times, December 21, 1998</ref> The Sealy and Domino's Pizza investments have been ranked by ''[[TheStreet.com]]'' as two of the five Romney-era investments by Bain Capital that had the biggest impact on American consumers; the other three were Staples and Sports Authority in the 1980s, and Brookstone in 1991.<ref name=Notte /> In 1997, when Bain invested in Sealy, the company already had a 23% share of the $4 billion mattress market, and Bain decided to make all parts of the mattress in a constant flow instead of in batches (thereby producing only the amount ordered by consumers and consequently reducing inventory), while redesigning the core mattress; Sealy's earnings increased by half in three years. Bain bought 93% of Domino's in 1998, and installed personnel who substantially boosted profits.<ref name=Notte /> As for Bain's purchase of film studio Artisan Entertainment in the late 1990s, Romney refused to get personally involved with it, because of its [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|R-rated]] films.<ref name=Notte />
[[Image:Domino's Pizza In Spring Hill,FLA.JPG|thumb|right|The exterior of a Domino's Pizza store in [[Spring Hill, Florida]].]]Much of the firm's profits were earned from a relatively small number of deals, with Bain Capital's overall success and failure rate being about even. One study of 68 deals that Bain Capital made up through the 1990s found that the firm lost money or broke even on 33 of them.<ref name="vf-excerpt">{{cite news | url=http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/2012/02/mitt-romney-201202.print | title=The Meaning of Mitt | author=[[Michael Kranish|Kranish, Michael]] | author2=Helman, Scott | magazine=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] | date=February 2012}}</ref> Another study that looked at the eight-year period following 77 deals during the same time found that in 17 cases the company went bankrupt or out of business, and in 6 cases Bain Capital lost all its investment. But 10 deals were very successful and represented 70 percent of the total profits.<ref name="wsj-bc">{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204331304577140850713493694 | title=Romney at Bain: Big Gains, Some Busts | author=Maremont, Mark | newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=January 9, 2012}}</ref> Bain Capital has publicly asserted that 80% of their 350 companies and 100 start-up investments grew as a result of Bain investments.<ref name=Ashley>Ashley Killough. [http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2012/08/30/romney-defends-sterling-business-record/comment-page-1/ "Romney defends 'sterling' business record'], CNN (August 30, 2012). Romney's web site defending his business career is at [http://www.sterlingbusinesscareer.com www.sterlingbusinesscareer.com].</ref>
Romney took a leave of absence from Bain Capital from November 1993<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8299040.html | title=Romney agrees to talk; union balks | first=Frank | last=Phillips | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=October 8, 1994}}</ref> to November 1994<ref name="bgseries4">{{Cite news|author=Swidey, Neil |author2=Ebbert, Stephanie |url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2007/06/27/raising_sons_rising_expectations/?page=full |title=The Making of Mitt Romney: Part 4: Journeys of a shared life: Raising sons, rising expectations bring unexpected turns |newspaper=The Boston Globe |date=June 27, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100112211501/http://www.boston.com/news/politics/2008/specials/romney/articles/part4_main/ |archivedate=January 12, 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }} Also [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8706571.html available in HighBeam]. Also available as [http://www.deseretnews.com/article/680196334/Romney-determined-to-make-mark-early.html "Romney determined to make mark early"], ''Deseret Morning News'', July 4, 2007.</ref> in order to run for the U.S. Senate. During that time, Ampad workers went on strike, and asked Romney to intervene; Bain Capital lawyers asked him not to get involved, although he did meet with the workers to tell them he had no position of active authority in the matter.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8299231.html | title=Romney meets with strikers Ind. workers say nothing resolved | first=Meg | last=Vaillancourt | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=October 10, 1994}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8310951.html | title=Strike-bound factory tied to Romney during US Senate race is set to close | first=Frank | last=Phillips | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=January 5, 1995}}</ref>
Romney returned to Bain Capital the day after the 1994 election, but the loss had a lasting effect; he told his brother, "I never want to run for something again unless I can win."<ref name="bgseries4"/><ref name="nyt-olympics-edge"/> When his father died in 1995, Mitt donated his inheritance to BYU's [[Marriott school#Organization and research|George W. Romney Institute of Public Management]].<ref name="lamb20060319">{{cite interview | title=Gov. Mitt Romney (R-Massachusetts) | date=March 19, 2006 | url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?191449-1/qa-mitt-romney | last=Romney | first=Mitt | interviewer=[[Brian Lamb]] | work=[[Q&A (U.S. talk show)|Q&A]] | publisher=[[C-SPAN]]}}</ref> He also joined the board, as vice-chair, of the [[Points of Light Foundation]],<ref name="dn082001">{{cite news | url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/859621/Public-service-for-Romney.html | title=Public service for Romney | author=Roche, Lisa Riley | author2=Bernick Jr., Bob | newspaper=Deseret News | location=Salt Lake City | date=August 20, 2001}}</ref> which had incorporated his father's [[National Volunteer Center]].
In 1994, Bain invested in [[Steel Dynamics]], based in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]], a prosperous steel company that has grown to the fifth largest in the U.S.A, employs about 6,100 people, and produces carbon steel products with 2010 revenues of $6.3 billion on steel shipments of 5.3 million tons.<ref>Hoover, Ken (January 13, 2012).[http://news.investors.com/article/597772/201201131836/mitt-romney-bain-capital-funded-steel-dynamics.htm Mitt Romney-Led Bain Funded Steel Dynamics' Success]. ''Investors Business Daily''</ref> In 1993, Bain acquired the [[Kansas City Bolt and Nut Company plant|Armco Worldwide Grinding System]] steel plant in [[Kansas City, Missouri]] and merged it with its steel plant in [[Georgetown, South Carolina]] to form [[GST Steel]]. The Kansas City plant had a strike in 1997.<ref name="kansascity1">{{cite web|last=Helling |first=Dave |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2012/01/06/3356924/bain-capital-tied-to-bankruptcy.html |title=Bain Capital tied to bankruptcy, closing of KC steel plant |publisher=KansasCity.com |date=2012-01-06 |accessdate=2012-02-01}}</ref><ref name="kansascity2">{{cite web|author=David Wren |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2012/01/14/3370204/romneys-bain-made-millions-as.html |title=Romney's Bain made millions as S.C. steelmaker went bankrupt |publisher=KansasCity.com |accessdate=2012-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kchistory.org/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/Local&CISOPTR=22900&CISOBOX=1&REC=14 |title=Missouri Valley Special Collections : Item Viewer |publisher=Kchistory.org |date=2001-02-08 |accessdate=2012-02-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116234803/http://www.kchistory.org/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=%2FLocal&CISOPTR=22900&CISOBOX=1&REC=14# |archive-date=2013-01-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="reuters1">{{cite news|last=Sullivan |first=Andy |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/06/us-campaign-romney-bailout-idUSTRE8050LL20120106 |title=Special report: Romney's steel skeleton in the Bain closet |publisher=Reuters |date= January 6, 2012|accessdate=2012-02-01}}</ref>
Bain's investment in [[Dade Behring]] represented a significant investment in the [[medical diagnostics]] industry. In 1994, Bain, together with [[Goldman Sachs Capital Partners]] completed a carveout acquisition of Dade International,<ref>[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Dade-Behring-Holdings-Inc-Company-History.html fundinguniverse.com Dade Behring company history]. Funding Universe</ref> the medical diagnostics division of [[Baxter International]] in a $440 million acquisition. Dade's private equity owners merged the company with DuPont's [[in vitro]] diagnostics business in May 1996 and subsequently with the Behring Diagnostics division of [[Hoechst AG]] in 1997.<ref name=dade9910k>[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/942307/0000950131-00-002295.txt Dade Behring Form 10K 1999 Annual Report]. Securities and Exchange Commission, Filed March 30, 2000</ref> [[Aventis]], the successor of Hoechst, acquired 52% of the combined company.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/20/business/company-news-aventis-may-sell-controlling-stake-in-dade-behring.html Aventis May Sell Controlling Stake in Dade Behring]. New York Times, December 20, 2000</ref> In 1999, the company reported $1.3 billion of revenue and completed a $1.25 billion [[leveraged recapitalization]] that resulted in a payout to shareholders.<ref name=dade9910k /> The dividend, taken together with other previous shareholder dividends resulted in an eightfold return on investment to Bain Capital and Goldman Sachs.<ref name="nyt-dade">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/13/us/politics/after-mitt-romney-deal-company-showed-profits-and-then-layoffs.html| title=After a Romney Deal, Profits and Then Layoffs | author=Barbaro, Michael | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=November 13, 2011 | page=A1}}</ref><ref name="wsj-bc"/>
In July 1996, when partner Bob Gray’s teenage daughter went missing in New York City, Romney shut down the Boston office and sent 56 employees to search for her, also setting up a toll-free tip line, and hiring private investigators. The search took Romney into contact with runaways on the seediest streets of New York, and a traced telephone call helped to locate the daughter, who had travelled to New Jersey for a concert without telling her parents.<ref>Michael Kranish, Scott Helman ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZP3-rXn0H8sC&pg=PT221 The Real Romney]'', page 221 (HarperCollins 2012).</ref>
In 1998, an affiliate of Bain Capital called Brookside Capital Partners Fund bought about 6 percent of Global Tech, a Chinese appliance-maker. Romney was the sole shareholder, sole director, president and chief executive officer of Brookside.<ref>Viser, Matt. [https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2012/09/25/chinese-firm-promoted-its-low-wage-low-tax-liability-investors-shortly-before-mitt-romney-made-investment/7BqBkvSXJnFrpmn7PRIMzJ/story.html "Chinese firm promoted its low-wage, low-tax liability to investors shortly before Mitt Romney made investment"], Boston Globe (September 25, 2012).</ref> The Obama campaign asserts that Romney profited from and indirectly supported "sweatshop conditions" at Global Tech, although independent fact-checkers say there is no evidence Romney actively sent any American jobs to China or approved the specific investment in Global Tech.<ref>Dwyer, Devin. [http://abcnews.go.com/m/blogEntry?id=17370190 "Obama Ad Says Romney Backed 'Sweatshop' Conditions in China"], ABC (October 1, 2012).</ref>
By the end of the decade, Bain Capital was on its way to being one of the top private equity firms in the nation,<ref name="nyt060407db"/> having increased its number of partners from 5 to 18, having 115 employees overall, and having $4 billion under its management.<ref name="howmakemoney"/><ref name="blum"/> The firm's average annual return on investments was 113 percent.<ref name="MrPowerPoint" /><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-7751688.html|title=Business record helps, hinders Romney|first=Thomas|last=Farragher|first2=Scott Bernard|last2=Nelson|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=October 24, 2002|page=A1}}{{subscription required}}</ref> It had made between 100 and 150 deals where it acquired and then sold a company.<ref name="vf-excerpt"/><ref name="nyt-dade"/><ref name="wsj-bc"/> Bain Capital's approach of applying consulting expertise to the companies it invested in became widely copied within the private equity industry.<ref name="blum"/><ref name="fortune-2007">{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2007/07/09/100121803/index.htm | title=The Republicans' Mr. Fix-it | author=Vickers, Marcia | magazine=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | date=June 27, 2007}}</ref>
Economist [[Steven Kaplan (economist)|Steven Kaplan]] of the [[University of Chicago]] would later say, "[Romney] came up with a model that was very successful and very innovative and that now everybody uses."<ref name="nym-onep"/> Kaplan argues that, "Bain Capital and Romney delivered spectacularly well for their customers, better than other [private equity] firms that on average outperformed the public markets. Today, those customers include the California State Teachers’ Retirement System and the Teacher Retirement System of Texas."<ref>Steven N. Kaplan. [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-12-15/romney-honed-right-skills-in-private-equity-commentary-by-steven-kaplan.html “Romney Honed the Right Skills in Private Equity: Steven Kaplan”], Bloomberg (December 14, 2011).</ref>
In contrast to economist Kaplan, the author and polemicist [[Matt Taibbi]] of ''[[Rolling Stone|Rolling Stone Magazine]]'' paints a less favorable portrait of Romney's business career (Taibbi also disparages Romney as “self-righteously anal, thin-lipped, [and] Whitest Kids U Know”). According to Taibbi, toward the middle of his career at Bain Capital, Romney moved away from helping startups, and moved toward [[leveraged buyout]]s which involved borrowing money to take over established companies in order to extract as much value as possible from those targeted companies. Taibbi calls this “financial piracy”, while acknowledging that Romney’s leveraged buyouts were not [[hostile takeover]]s, and also conceding that some of Bain’s work was not "evil" (such as Bain's successful turnaround of Experian). Taibbi blames the [[Internal Revenue Code|U.S. tax code]] for making leveraged buyouts possible by allowing companies like Bain to deduct interest on debt they use to acquire targets, and also by allowing individuals like Romney to pay much less than the ordinary tax rate on income.<ref>Matt Taibbi. [https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/greed-and-debt-the-true-story-of-mitt-romney-and-bain-capital-20120829 "Greed and Debt: The True Story of Mitt Romney and Bain Capital"], ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' (August 29, 2012).</ref> However, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reports that Romney likely did not participate in the latter tax rate reductions.<ref>Mark Maremont. [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390444506004577618071359294552 “Romney Didn't Participate in Bain Fee Waiver, Attorney Says”], ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' (August 28, 2012).</ref>
Romney primarily made his fortune at Bain Capital from 1984 to 1999, a fortune estimated to be worth between $190 million to $250 million.<ref>Andrew Jackson. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=pIMACOruWRoC&pg=PA77 The Mormon Faith of Mitt Romney: What Latter-Day Saints Teach and Practice]'', page 77 (Kudu Publishing Services 2012).</ref>
==Departure from business career: 1999–2002== [[File:Romney Olympics.JPG|thumb|left|alt=Photograph of Romney standing with microphone in middle of curling lanes|Romney left his business career to run the [[2002 Winter Olympics]].]]As the decade neared a close, the goal of simply making more money was losing its appeal for Romney.<ref name="bgseries4"/><ref name="nyt-olympics-edge">{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/19/us/politics/19romney.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all | title=In Olympics Success, Romney Found New Edge | author=Johnson, Kirk | newspaper=The New York Times | date=September 19, 2007}}</ref> He took a paid leave of absence from Bain Capital in February 1999 when he became the head of the [[Salt Lake Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games of 2002|Salt Lake Organizing Committee]] for the [[2002 Winter Olympics]].<ref name="dn-cross"/><ref name=WP071212>{{cite news|title=Mitt Romney and his departure from Bain|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/post/mitt-romney-and-his-departure-from-bain/2012/07/12/gJQAASzUfW_blog.html|accessdate=July 14, 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=July 12, 2012|author=Glenn Kessler|format=blog by expert}}</ref> The decision caused turmoil at Bain Capital, with a power struggle ensuing.<ref name="real-depart"/> Some partners left and founded the [[Audax Group]] and [[Golden Gate Capital]].<ref name="bg-reins">{{cite news | url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/articles/2012/07/20/romney_kept_reins_bargained_hard_on_severance/?page=full | title=Romney kept reins, bargained hard on severance | first=Beth | last=Healy | first2=Michael | last2=Kranish | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=July 20, 2012}}</ref> Other partners threatened to leave, and there was a prospect of eight-figure lawsuits being filed.<ref name="real-depart">Michael Kranish, Scott Helman ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZP3-rXn0H8sC&pg=PT221 The Real Romney]'', page 206-207 (HarperCollins 2012).</ref> Romney was worried that the firm might be destroyed, but the crisis ebbed.<ref name="real-depart"/>
Billed in some public statements as keeping a part-time role,<ref name="bg-reins"/><ref>{{cite news | newspaper=[[Boston Herald]] | first=Greg | last=Gatlin | title=Romney Looks To Restore Olympic Pride | date= February 12, 1999 | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-57110202.html}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Romney remained the firm's sole shareholder, managing director, CEO and president, signing corporate and legal documents, attending to his interests within the firm, and conducting prolonged negotiations for the terms of his departure.<ref name="bg-reins"/><ref name="ap-exit">{{cite news | url=http://www.macombdaily.com/article/20120725/NEWS06/120729692/fact-check-romney-met-bain-partners-after-exit&pager=full_story | title=Fact Check: Romney Met Bain Partners After Exit | first=Stephen | last=Braun | first2=Jack | last2=Gillum | agency=[[Associated Press]] | newspaper=[[The Macomb Daily]] | date=July 25, 2012}}</ref>
Romney was not involved in day-to-day operations of the firm after starting the Olympics position.<ref>{{cite news | url= http://factcheck.org/2012/08/is-romney-to-blame-for-cancer-death/ | title= Is Romney to Blame for Cancer Death?| publisher=[[FactCheck]] | date= August 8, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Mitt Romney and backers use ‘day-to-day’ to reshape questions about Bain |url= http://www.boston.com/politicalintelligence/2012/07/16/mitt-romney-and-backers-use-day-day-reshape-questions-about-bain/1eFGBl8dO9uOZvjXyViomM/story.html |accessdate=August 13, 2012|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=July 16, 2012|author=Callum Borchers}}</ref> Those were handled by a management committee, consisting of five of the fourteen remaining active partners with the firm.<ref name="bg-reins"/> However, according to some interviews and press releases during 1999, Romney said he was keeping a part-time function at Bain.<ref name="bg-reins"/><ref>Mitt Romney, quoted by the Boston Herald in February 1999 (Greg Gatlin, “Romney Looks To Restore Olympic Pride,” The Boston Herald, February 12, 1999)</ref>
During his leave of absence, Romney continued to be listed in filings to the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]<ref name=SECBain>{{cite web|title=SCHEDULE 13D (Rule 13d-101)|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1054290/000092701601001009/0000927016-01-001009-0001.txt|publisher=Securities and Exchange Commission|accessdate=July 14, 2012|author=Bain Capital Fund VI, L.P.|date=February 20, 2001|quote=Bain Capital, Inc., a Delaware corporation ("Bain Capital"), is the sole managing partner of the BCIP entities. Mr. W. Mitt Romney is the sole shareholder, sole director, Chief Executive Officer and President of Bain Capital and thus is the controlling person of Bain Capital.}}</ref> as "sole shareholder, sole director, Chief Executive Officer and President".<ref>{{cite web|last=Marshall|first=John|title=No, Romney Didn’t Leave Bain in 1999 |url=http://talkingpointsmemo.com/archives/2012/07/no_romney_didnt_leave_bain_in_1999.php?ref=fpblg|accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Borchers|first=Callum|title=Mitt Romney stayed at Bain 3 years longer than he stated|url=http://bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2012/07/11/government-documents-indicate-mitt-romney-continued-bain-after-date-when-says-left/IpfKYWjnrsel4pvCFbsUTI/story.html|publisher=Christopher M. Mayer|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> The SEC filings reflected the legal reality<ref name="msn-hayes"/> and the ownership interest in the Bain Capital management company.<ref name="nyt-whenback"/><ref name="ap-exit"/> In practice, former Bain partners have stated that Romney's attention was mostly occupied by his Olympics position.<ref name="msn-hayes">{{cite news | url=http://upwithchrishayes.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/07/15/12751962-former-bain-capital-partner-says-romney-was-legally-ceo-of-bain-capital-until-2002?lite | title=Former Bain Capital partner says Romney was 'legally' CEO of Bain Capital until 2002 | author=Gentile, Sal | publisher=[[msnbc.com]] | date=July 15, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719012532/http://upwithchrishayes.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/07/15/12751962-former-bain-capital-partner-says-romney-was-legally-ceo-of-bain-capital-until-2002?lite | archivedate=July 19, 2012 | df= }}</ref><ref name="cnn-king">{{cite web|last=King|first=John|title=John King: Why is 1999 so important in 2012?|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/12/politics/john-king-bain/index.html?hpt=hp_c1|publisher=CNN|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> He did stay in regular contact with his partners, and traveled to meet with them several times, signing corporate and legal documents and paying attention to his own interests within the firm and to his departure negotiations.<ref name="ap-exit" /> Bain Capital Fund VI in 1998 was the last one Romney was involved in; investors were worried that with Romney gone, the firm would have trouble raising money for Bain Capital Fund VII in 2000, but in practice the $2.5 billion was raised without much trouble.<ref name="bg-reins"/> His former partners have said that Romney had no role in assessing other new investments after February 1999,<ref name="bg-reins" /> nor was he involved in directing the company’s investment funds.<ref name="nyt-whenback" /> Discussions over the final terms of Romney's departure dragged on during this time, with Romney negotiating for the best deal he could get and his continuing position as CEO and sole shareholder giving him the leverage to do so.<ref name="bg-reins"/><ref name="msn-hayes"/>
Although he had left open the possibility of returning to Bain after the Olympics, Romney made his crossover to politics permanent with an announcement in August 2001.<ref name="dn-cross">{{cite news | url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/859621/Public-service-for-Romney.html | title=Public service for Romney | author=Roche, Lisa Riley | author2=Bernick Jr., Bob | newspaper=[[Deseret News]] | date=August 20, 2001}}</ref> His separation from the firm was finalized in early 2002.<ref name="bg-reins"/><ref>{{cite news | last=Charles | first=Deborah | title=Romney faces new questions over tenure at Bain | agency=Reuters | newspaper=Chicago Tribune | date=July 12, 2012 | url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-07-12/news/sns-rt-us-usa-campaign-romney-bainbre86b1gd-20120712_1_bain-investments-bain-capital-mitt-romney}}</ref> Romney negotiated a ten-year retirement agreement with Bain Capital<ref name="bg-reins"/> that allowed him to receive a passive profit share and interest as a retired partner in some Bain Capital entities, including buyout and Bain Capital investment funds, in exchange for his ownership in the management company.<ref name="nyt-depagr">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/19/us/politics/retirement-deal-keeps-bain-money-flowing-to-romney.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all | title=Buyout Profits Keep Flowing to Romney | author=Confessore, Nicholas | author2=Drew, Christopher | author3=Creswell, Julie | newspaper=The New York Times | date=December 18, 2011}}</ref><ref name="personalworth">{{Cite news |first=Jim |last=Kuhnhenn |title=Romney Worth As Much As $250 Million |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,293140,00.html |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=August 14, 2007 |access-date=2012-08-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204023043/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,293140,00.html# |archive-date=2012-02-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Because the private equity business continued to thrive, this deal would bring him millions of dollars in annual income.<ref name="nyt-depagr"/> Romney was the first and last CEO of Bain Capital; since his departure became final, it has continued to be run by management committee.<ref name="bg-reins"/>
Romney's business career has drawn both praise and criticism from his political opponents.<ref name=Byron>Byron Tau. [http://www.politico.com/politico44/2012/05/clinton-romneys-business-record-sterling-124980.html Bill Clinton: Mitt Romney's business record 'sterling'], [[Politico]] (May 31, 2012).</ref> Summarizing his business career and the [[creative destruction]] of the private equity industry, he has said: "Sometimes the medicine is a little bitter but it is necessary to save the life of the patient. My job was to try to make the enterprise successful, and in my view the best security a family can have is that the business they work for is strong."<ref name="nyt060407db"/> Romney's web site defends his business career.<ref name=Ashley />
==Personal wealth generated by business career== As a result of his career in business, Romney and his wife amassed a net worth in the hundreds of millions of dollars; their wealth remained in the range of a fifth to a quarter billion dollars as of 2011.<ref name="personalworth"/><ref name="bg-discl-2011">{{cite news | url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/articles/2011/08/13/romney_worth_between_190m_and_250m_campaign_says/ | title=Romney's net worth pegged at $190–$250M | author=Viser, Matt | newspaper=The Boston Globe | date=August 13, 2011}}</ref> Most of it has been held in [[blind trust]]s since 2003.<ref name="personalworth" /><ref name="bg-discl-2011" /> An additional blind trust, valued at $100 million in 2012, exists in the name of the Romneys' children.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dixon|first=Kim|title=Q+A: What Romney's taxes reveal – and what they omit|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/24/us-usa-taxes-romney-idUSTRE80N07320120124|publisher=Reuters|date=January 24, 2012}}</ref> The trust, created in 1995, allows the Romneys to transfer money to heirs outside their estate, taking advantage of sophisticated [[tax planning]] techniques used by high-net-worth families in an effort to defer or reduce their tax burden.<ref>{{cite news | url= http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-08-26/romney-tax-returns-show-strategy-for-moving-money-to-kids#p1 | title= Romney Tax Returns Show Strategy for Moving Money | first=Margaret |last=Collins |first2=Richard |last2=Rubin |magazine=Bloomberg Businessweek | date=August 27, 2012}}</ref> Romney has an [[SEP-IRA]] worth between $21 million and $102 million.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-07-15/the-secret-behind-romney-s-magical-ira.html | title=The Secret Behind Romney's Magical IRA | first=William D. | last=Cohan | publisher=Bloomberg News | date=July 15, 2012}}</ref> A portion of Romney's financial assets are held in [[offshore account]]s and investments.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/2012/08/investigating-mitt-romney-offshore-accounts | title=Where the Money Lives | first=Nicholas | last=Shaxson | magazine=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] | date=August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/02/us/politics/bains-offshore-strategies-grew-romneys-wealth.html?hp&pagewanted=all | title=Offshore Tactics Helped Increase Romneys' Wealth | first=Michael | last=Luo | first2=Mike | last2=McIntire | newspaper=The New York Times | date=October 1, 2012}}</ref>
In 2010, Romney and his wife received $21.7 million in income, almost all of it from investments such as [[dividends]], [[capital gains]], and [[carried interest]].<ref name="csm-taxes" /> For 2010, the Romneys paid about $3 million in federal income taxes, for an effective tax rate of 13.9 percent.<ref name="csm-taxes">{{cite news | url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Elections/President/2012/0124/Romney-tax-return-shows-he-paid-3-million.-His-tax-plan-wouldn-t-bump-that | title=Romney tax return shows he paid $3 million. His tax plan wouldn't bump that | first=Ron | last=Scherer | newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor | date=January 24, 2012}}</ref> For the years 1990–2009, his effective rates were at least 13.7 percent with an average effective rate of 20.2 percent.<ref name="pol-taxes11">{{cite news | url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0912/81528.html | title=Mitt Romney releases 2011 tax returns | first=Ginger | last=Gibson | newspaper=Politico | date=September 21, 2012}}</ref>
Romney has regularly [[tithe]]d to the LDS Church, including stock from Bain Capital holdings.<ref>{{cite news|publisher = [[ABC News]]|url = http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/mitt-romney-millions-mormon-church/story?id=15380149#.TxiUH2_lMuY|first1 = Matthew|last1 = Mosk|first2 = Brian|last2 = Ross|authorlink2 = Brian Ross (journalist)|date = January 18, 2012|title = Mitt Romney Sent Millions to Mormon Church}}</ref> In 2010, he and his wife gave $3 million to charity, including $1.5 million to the church.<ref name="csm-taxes" /> The Romney family's Tyler Charitable Foundation gave out about $650,000 in that year, some of which went to organizations that fight diseases such as [[cystic fibrosis]] and [[multiple sclerosis]].<ref>{{cite news|first = Mary|last = Moore|newspaper = [[Boston Business Journal]]|date = January 24, 2012|url = http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2012/01/24/romney-foundation-gives-210k-in-boston.html|title=Boston MS charities get big gifts from Romney foundation}}</ref> In addition, the Romneys have often donated to LDS Church-owned BYU.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/29/mitt-romney-mormon-faith_n_1834466.html?view=print&comm_ref=false |title=Mitt Romney Holds Mormon Faith Close Through Political Rise|first= Jaweed|last= Kaleem|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|date= August 29, 2012}}</ref> For the years 1990–2009, the Romneys' total charitable donations as portions of their income averaged 13.5 percent.<ref name="pol-taxes11" />

Carol Ohmart Pictures.|website=Glamourgirlsofthesilverscreen.com|accessdate= September 30, 2017}} }} '''Armelia Carol Ohmart''' (July 3, 1927 – January 1, 2002),{{cite journal|work=Voice of the Theatre|publisher=Alex Film Society|location=Los Angeles, California|p=5|title=Guests of the House: Carol Ohmart|author=Harris, Linda|date=October 28, 2006|volume=12|issue=3|url=http://www.alexfilmsociety.org/newsletters/HouseOnHH_VOT_WEB.pdf}} known professionally as '''Carol Ohmart''', was an American actress and former model who appeared in numerous films and television series from the early 1950s until the 1970s. Over the duration of her career, she would appear in several notable [[horror film|horror]] and [[film noir]]s, including lead roles in ''[[The Wild Party (1956 film)|The Wild Party]]'' (1956) and [[William Castle]]'s ''[[House on Haunted Hill]]'' (1959). Born to a [[Mormonism|Mormon]] family in [[Salt Lake City]], Ohmart spent the majority of her early life in [[Seattle]] and [[Spokane, Washington|Spokane]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. After graduating high school, she returned to Utah where she won the title of [[Miss Utah]], and subsequently placed fourth in the [[Miss America]] pageant. Her appearance in pageants led to modeling work, which included posing for artist [[Milton Caniff]]. Ohmart made her feature film debut in [[Michael Curtiz]]'s ''[[The Scarlet Hour]]'' in 1956, followed by various television appearances, as well as roles in several horror films, such as ''House on Haunted Hill'' (1959) and ''[[Spider Baby]]'' (1968). Her final film appearance was in ''The Spectre of Edgar Allan Poe'' (1974), after which she formally retired from acting, dedicating her time to studying [[New Age]] philosophy and spiritualism. Ohmart spent the majority of her later life in Seattle, before dying of natural causes in [[Fort Collins, Colorado]] in 2002, aged 74. ==Early life== Ohmart was born Armelia Carol Ohmart on July 3, 1927{{cite web|title=Biographical Summaries of Notable People: Carol Ohmart|url=https://www.myheritage.com/research/record-10182-558221/carol-ohmart-in-biographical-summaries-of-notable-people|accessdate=February 22, 2018|via=[[MyHeritage]]}} in [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]], into a [[Mormon]] family. Her parents were C. Thomas Ohmart, a dentist who was first a professional actor, and his wife, Armelia Ohmart. Her family relocated to [[Seattle|Seattle, Washington]] shortly after Ohmart's birth.{{efn-lr|Public records for King County, Washington, show Armelia Carol Ohmart, age 2, a resident of Seattle."United States Census, 1930," database with images, [https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:XC3H-NJ5 FamilySearch] (accessed February 23, 2018), Armelia C Ohmart in household of C Thomas Ohmart, Seattle, King, Washington, United States; citing enumeration district (ED) ED 98, sheet 14A, line 6, family 229, NARA microfilm publication T626 (Washington D.C.: National Archives and Records Administration, 2002), roll 2497; FHL microfilm 2,342,231.}} At age twelve, Ohmart sang on [[KFRC (defunct)|KFRC]] in San Francisco, California. She also sang on [[KSL (radio)|KSL]], KUTA and [[KDYL]] in her hometown of Salt Lake City. Additionally, she sang with dance bands, including that of [[Jan Garber]], as a teenager.{{cite news|title='Miss Utah' Was Beauty Even as One-Year-Old|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5982127/the_salt_lake_tribune/|work=The Salt Lake Tribune|agency=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=September 27, 1945|location=Utah, Salt Lake "Copper Calhoun" in [[Milton Caniff]]'s ''[[Steve Canyon]]'' comic strip.{{cite web|url=http://www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/1947-photo-cartoonist-milt-caniff-draws-copper|title=1947 Photo Cartoonist Books|p=50|title=Dawn to Dusk with Milton Caniff}} ==Career== === Television === Ohmart was seen on early television doing commercials, appearing on NBC's ''Bonny Maid Versatile Varieties'' (1949–51), which aired Friday nights at 9 p.m. Ohmart was seen pitching floor wax along with [[Anne Francis]] and [[Eva Marie Saint]], the other two hosts of the show. She also worked on ''[[The 20th Century Fox Hour]]''.{{cite book|last1=Prickette|first1=James|title=Actors of the Spaghetti Westerns|date=2012|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=9781469144290|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Q1SAAAAQBAJ&pg=RA6-PA1952&dq=%22Carol+Ohmart%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjX86PTmovOAhUkzIMKHVdTAOsQ6AEIMDAD#v=onepage&q=%22Carol%20Ohmart%22&f=false|accessdate=24 July 2016|language=en}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}} Ohmart moved to New York in 1955 where she worked as an understudy on Broadway. She had steady work in television until the early 1970s, with guest roles in ''[[Bat Masterson]]'', ''[[Ripcord (TV series)|Ripcord]]'', ''[[The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp]]'', ''[[Get Smart]]'', ''[[Perry Mason]]'' [[Tombstone Territory]] and ''[[Barnaby Jones]]''.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} ===Film=== Dubbed a "female Brando" by the press,{{cite news|last1=Bacon|first1=James|title=Female Bombshell|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5982668/the_daily_herald/|work=The Daily Herald|date=July 3, 1955|location=Utah, Provo|page=14|via=Newspapers.com|accessdate=July 23, 2016}} {{Open access}} [[Paramount Pictures]] signed her in 1955 and promoted her as the next [[Marilyn Monroe]].{{sfn|Jorgensen|2010|p=245}} Ohmart had top billing in ''[[The Scarlet Hour]]'', a Paramount film made by the distinguished director [[Michael Curtiz]] about a married woman who persuades her lover to commit a jewelry robbery. Ohmart recalled of the film: "It was the wrong vehicle to launch me as a star. [[Frank Tashlin]], one of the film's three screenwriters, told me that it had been earlier turned down by [[Barbara Stanwyck]]. Foolishly, Paramount let its new leading lady portray a lush, an adulteress wife and a suicide by the film's end." After nearly $2 million spent promoting her, Ohmart was released from her contract. She co-starred with [[Anthony Quinn]] in a 1956 crime drama, ''[[The Wild Party (1956 film)|The Wild Party]]''.{{sfn|Maltin|1994|p=1452}} After marrying [[Wayde Preston]], she briefly retired from acting, only to return a year later, in films and television. Producer [[Jack M. Warner|Jack Warner]] offered her a supporting role in ''[[Born Reckless (1958 film)|Born Reckless]]'' (1958). Although she did not like the script, she took the role. One of her most noted roles was in [[William Castle]]'s ''[[House on Haunted Hill]]'' (1959), playing a murderous wife.{{cite web|url=http://www.briansdriveintheater.com/carolohmart.html|title=Carol Ohmart at Brian's Drive-In Theater|website=Briansdriveintheater.com|accessdate=30 September 2017}} In 1962, she returned to New York City to appear in an off-Broadway production titled ''Banderol''. This was followed by a supporting part in the [[Denis Sanders]]-directed ''[[One Man's Way]]'' (1964). Ohmart took a hiatus from appearing in films for several years, selling real estate and becoming involved in studying [[spiritualism]], and ended up in debt. In 1967, she appeared in the exploitation film ''Caxambu!'', followed by a lead role in the cult horror film ''[[Spider Baby]]''; according to director [[Jack Hill]], Ohmart was enthusiastic about the project, asking, "Do you think we can win an Academy Award for this?" Her last film role was in 1974's ''The Spectre of Edgar Allan Poe''.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} ==Personal life== Ohmart married three times, most notably to actor [[Wade Preston]]. They wed in 1956 and were divorced in 1958. Her first marriage, in 1949, was to actor Ken Grayson; it was annulled in 1951.{{cite journal|last1=Wagner|first1=Laura|title=Carol Ohmart: "I've Found My Peace"|journal=Films of the Golden Age|date=Summer 2015|issue=81|pages=56–58}} In 1978, she married William Traberth in [[Wyoming]], a veteran and former firefighter, and retired in [[Sequim, Washington]], a suburb of Seattle. She changed her name to Kariomar S. Traberth, taking her husband's surname, and was guarded about her private life. Throughout the late 1960s and 1970s, Ohmart dedicated much of her time studying [[spiritualism]] and [[New Age]] philosophy, which served as a basis for various poems and short stories she wrote. Around 1973, while filming an episode of ''[[Barnaby Jones]]'' in Los Angeles, Ohmart was attacked and beaten by three men on a street in Hollywood. After being discharged from the hospital over her injuries, Ohmart was prescribed pain killers, which marked the beginnings of a years-long addiction to prescription medication. In 1989, Ohmart agreed to be the subject of an extensive profile in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.{{cite web|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title=Rediscovering the Last Starlet : A mysterious phone call leads to Carol Ohmart|date=January 8, 1989|accessdate=February 22, 2018|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-01-08/entertainment/ca-255_1_carol-ohmart|author=Barrios, Gregg}} In the profile, Ohmart revealed that she had an estranged relationship with her mother, who did not know of her daughter's whereabouts for the last ten years of her life, up until her death in 1987. Ohmart recalled: {{quote|Until I became of legal age, I was terrorized. It was hammered into me that God's command was to love your mother or God will kill you...I forgave her, but I haven't forgotten. How could I? I tried to be a dutiful daughter, I wrote her all those (hundreds of) letters, but she never let me live my own life. She tried to live through me. I appreciated her supporting me during the lean years, but she wasn't doing it for me, it was for her own selfish ends, to keep me taking orders. She controlled my life.}} ==Death== Ohmart died in [[Fort Collins, Colorado]] on January 1, 2002, aged 74, of natural causes.Wilson, Scott. ''Resting Places: The Burial Sites of More Than 14,000 Famous Persons'' 3rd ed. (Jefferson, NC: McFarland, 2016; {{ISBN|978-0-7864-7992-4}}), [https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=FOHgDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA561&lpg=PA561#v=onepage&q&f=false page 561] She was cremated, and her ashes scattered over [[Carter Lake (Colorado)|Carter Lake]] in [[Loveland, Colorado]]. ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{for|the American chemist|Charles W. Crawford (chemist)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use British English|date=May 2015}} [[File:TB107 in 1900 or 1901.jpg|thumb|Her Majesty's Torpedo Boat 107, launched 1900 or 1901, that was to come under the command of Crawford]] Captain '''Charles Wispington Glover Crawford''', [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] (1873 – 16 October 1934) was a British [[Royal Navy]] officer who commanded the [[HMNB Devonport|Devonport]] flotilla of motor torpedo boats. In his spare time he was a noted [[philatelist]]. He signed the [[Roll of Distinguished Philatelists]] in 1934.<ref>''[http://www.abps.org.uk/Awards/Roll_of_Distinguished_Philatelists/RDP_Background_20111231_LR.pdf Background notes on The Roll of Distinguished Philatelists September 2011]'', Roll of Distinguished Philatelists Trust, London, 2011. [https://www.webcitation.org/6OlHSBOTl Archived here.]</ref>
==Naval career== Crawford was educated for a naval career and joined the {{HMS|Britannia|1860|2}} at [[Dartmouth, Devon|Dartmouth]] in 1886. He became a [[midshipman]] on {{HMS|Northumberland|1866|6}} in 1888 and later that same year joined {{HMS|Canada|1881|6}} at [[Bermuda]]. In 1893 he became [[Lieutenant (Royal Navy)|lieutenant]], and in the middle of 1902 he was posted as first lieutenant and torpedo officer to the [[protected cruiser]] [[HMS Highflyer (1898)|HMS ''Highflyer'']], flag ship of the [[East Indies Station]].<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Naval & Military intelligence |day_of_week=Saturday |date=5 July 1902 |page_number=9 |issue=36812}}</ref> He subsequently attained the rank of [[Commander (Royal Navy)|commander]] and in 1905 was given the command of a Royal Navy motor [[torpedo boat]] HMTB ''107'' launched in 1901.<ref>[http://www.battleships-cruisers.co.uk/navy_list_1908_other_lists.htm Navy List 1908 Other Lists – Crew Lists], battleships-cruisers.co.uk, retrieved 16 August 2014</ref> Crawford was also given command of the Devonport flotilla of the 160 footer torpedo boats.<ref>[http://www.fleetorganization.com/1906rntorpedoboats.html Torpedo Boats in Home Waters], RN June 1906, retrieved 16 August 2014</ref>
He travelled widely and was in charge of [[wireless telegraphy]] in [[Somaliland]] in actions against [[Mohammed Abdullah Hassan]], known as the "Mad Mullah" by the British.<ref name=LP/> He retired in 1910 but was recalled to active service on the outbreak of the First World War. He was involved with the landing of the naval division at [[Dunkirk]] and the evacuation of [[Ostend]] for which he was [[mentioned in dispatches]].<ref name=LP>"The Late Captain C.W.G. Crawford, C.B.E., R.N.", R.B.Y., ''[[The London Philatelist]]'', Vol. XLIII, No. 514, October 1934, pp. 205–7.</ref> In 1919 he was awarded the honour of being made a commander of the order of the British Empire in recognition of his work during the war.<ref>[http://www.naval-history.net/WW1NavyBritishLGDecorations1919a.htm 31432 - 1 JULY 1919], Naval History.net, retrieved 16 August 2014</ref>
==Philately== Crawford first became interested in stamps as a boy and formed a collection with his step-father. During his naval career he often sent stamps home from the various ports that he visited. His philatelic interests were broad but he was a particular expert on the stamps of the Australian States and New Zealand. He was elected to the [[Royal Philatelic Society London]] in June 1918 and was a member of their [[Philatelic expertisation|Expert Committee]]. He was convenor of the Queensland Reference List Committee who were charged with reporting on the [[Postage stamp paper|papers]], [[Stamp separation|perforations]] and [[Plating (philately)|plates]] of that territory.<ref name=LP/><ref name=abps>[http://www.abps.org.uk/Home/Who_Was_Who/index.xalter#C Who Was Who in British Philately], [[Association of British Philatelic Societies]], 2014. Retrieved 11 August 2014. [https://www.webcitation.org/5zDx9UBpl Archived here.]</ref>
==Death== Crawford died at his home in [[Seaford, East Sussex|Seaford]] on 16 October 1934 after having suffered two heart attacks in August of that year. He was buried at [[Morden Cemetery]] on 19 October and was survived by his wife.<ref name=LP/>
==Selected publications== *"Reflections on Modern Philately." The Eighth Philatelic Congress. *"Perforation Varieties of Victoria and their Arrangement." ''[[Gibbons Stamp Monthly|Stanley Gibbons Monthly Journal]]'', Vol. XX, p. 127. *" Perforations of the 1898-1910 Issues of China." ''Stanley Gibbons Monthly Journal'', Vol. XX, p. 369. *"The Flaw Varieties of the Electrotyped Issues of Queensland." ''[[The London Philatelist]]'', Vol. XXIX, page 191. *"New Zealand: The 1/2d. 'Newspaper Postage' Stamp, 1873–95." ''Stanley Gibbons Monthly Journal'', Vol. XXIII, p. 120. *"Introductory Notes to the 1906-08 Provisional Issues of Nicaragua." ''The London Philatelist'', Vol. XXXVI, p. 56. *"South Australia. The Is. olive-yellow, 1862." ''The London Philatelist'', Vol. XXXIV, p. 193. *"The Watermarked Papers used for the New Zealand 1/2d. Stamp, inscribed ' Newspaper Postage.' " ''The London Philatelist'', Vol. XXXIX, p. 84.

'''Cilydd''' is the father of [[Culhwch]], hero of the [[Middle Welsh]] prose tale ''[[Culhwch and Olwen]]'', the earliest of the collection usually referred to as the ''[[Mabinogion]]''. He is the son of Prince [[Celyddon]], husband to [[Goleuddydd]], who bore him his son. When Goleuddydd dies after giving birth to Culhwch, Cilydd hears about another woman, the wife of King Doged. Cilydd slays Doged and procures his lands and family, marrying the widow, who becomes Culhwch's hated stepmother.
==External links== *[https://archive.org/stream/mabinogion00unkngoog#page/n242/mode/2up Text of ''Culhwch and Olwen''], translated by [[Lady Charlotte Guest]].
