[[File:Rita Gorgon and Mieczysław Ettinger (trial 1933).JPG|right|thumb|300px|Gorgonowa with her attorney, Mieczysław Ettinger, during the trial in 1933]] '''Rita Gorgonowa''' (real name '''Emilia Margerita Gorgon''', née '''Ilic''') was a [[governess]], and main character of one of the most infamous crime stories of the [[Second Polish Republic]]. Born on 7 March 1901 in [[Knin]], [[Dalmatia]], [[Austria-Hungary]], she was found guilty of murder of Elzbieta Zaremba, daughter of Henryk Zaremba, an architect from [[Lwow]]. The murder, which took place on 30 December 1931, and the subsequent trial, were regarded as the biggest crime story of Poland at that time. Gorgonowa, who had a son and two daughters, died in unknown circumstances: her post-1939 fate has not been established.
== Early life == Emilia Margerita Ilic was either of Serbian or Croatian origin. Her father was a physician, who died when she was three. Her mother later remarried.
At the age of 15, Margerita married a Colonel of the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]], Erwin Gorgon. Probably in 1918 she gave birth to a son and settled in Lwow with her husband's family. In 1921, Erwin Gorgon left Poland and, in search of work, emigrated to the [[United States]]. Soon afterwards, Rita was forced by her in-laws to leave their house, as they had wrongly accused her of immoral behaviour{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}. Gorgonowa, who was regarded as a very attractive woman, left her son with the in-laws and supported herself by working as a governess.
== Working with the Zaremba family == In 1924, Gorgonowa became a governess at the house of the 41-year-old architect Henryk Zaremba. She lived at his villa in Brzuchowice, located 7 kilometers from Lwow. Prior to employing Gorgonowa, Zaremba had separated from his wife, who had been confined to an asylum as she suffered from mental problems{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}. Zaremba and his ex-wife had two children: a daughter, Elzbieta (Lusia), born in 1914 and a son, Stanislaw, born 1917.
In addition to her governess duties, Gorgonowa ran the house. After about a year, Gorgonowa and Zaremba began an affair which eventually let to daughter Romana's birth in 1928. Gorgonowa later claimed that she was hoping to marry the wealthy architect. Meanwhile, the close relationship between her father and her governess was noticed by teenage Lusia, who often argued about this with her father.
== Murder == In the night of 30–31 December 1931, Elzbieta (Lusia), who was sleeping in her bed, was hit in the head by a blunt object, probably an [[ice pick]], and died on the spot. The murder was discovered by Stanislaw Zaremba, who was awakened by a dog, and alarmed residents of the house. Doctor Ludwik Csala was called for, together with a police officer, who scanned the room.
Since circumstantial evidence pointed at Gorgonowa, she was immediately arrested. Also, Henryk Zaremba, suspected of cooperation with murderers, was locked for six weeks. Furthermore, police detectives interviewed a gardener and a teenage boy from Brzuchowice, who was secretly in love with Lusia.
During the interrogation, Gorgonowa maintained her innocence. Police specialists came to the conclusion, that the murder had been carried out by a resident of the house, as there were no footsteps on the windowsill and in the snow around the building. Furthermore, no traces of a break-in were found, and family dog Lux did not bark that night. According to official police report, Gorgonowa crossed the corridor from her room to Lusia's room, killing the girl. She then opened the window, and penetrated her victim's vagina with a finger, trying to make it appear as a rape. Upon leaving Lusia's room, Gorgonowa noticed Lux the dog, whom she hit in the head. The canine wailed, waking Stas Zaremba, who was sleeping in the dining room. The boy entered the corridor, noticing a person dressed in a sheepskin, standing next to a Christmas tree. Stas later claimed that it was Rita.
Unable to get back to her bedroom, Gorgonowa ran out through front door. While entering her bedroom, she broke a small window, cutting her finger. She then changed her nightdress and joined other residents of the house, who had been alarmed by Stas. On 31 December Gorgonowa threw the ice pick into a pool, losing a candle. Later on, a bloodstained handkerchief was found, also traces of blood were found on Rita's sheepskin. The blood on the handkerchief and the sheepskin was type A, while Gorgonowa's blood was type 0. Nevertheless, findings of police experts were undermined by famous scientist from Lwow, [[Ludwik Hirszfeld]].
== Trial == On 14 May 1932, after a short trial, District Court at Lwow sentenced Rita Gorgonowa to death. Due to a number of legal mistakes and appeals of her defence (Mieczyslaw Ettinger of [[Warszawa]], Jozef Wozniakowski of Kraków and Maurycy Axer of Lwow), the verdict was later changed by the Supreme Court. While in prison, Margerita gave birth to daughter Ewa, on 20 September 1932. In the meantime her case was moved to the District Court in [[Kraków]], which on 29 April 1933 sentenced Rita to eight years. Gorgonowa was to be released on 24 May 1940 but due to the [[German Invasion of Poland]] she was released on 3 September 1939.
Further fate of Rita Gorgonowa is unknown. Her daughters claim that she survived [[World War II]]. According to some sources, she moved to [[Silesia]] or ran a newsstand in [[Opole]]. Other sources claim that she left Poland and settled in [[South America]].
In 1977, a feature film ''The Case of Gorgonowa'' was made by director [[Janusz Majewski (director)|Janusz Majewski]], with [[Ewa Dalkowska]] playing the role of Rita. In 2014 Rita's daughter Ewa and daughter in-law Margarita Ilic-Lisowska declared their intention to re-open the trial and change of the verdict.
==See also== *[[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]]
== Sources == * Edmund Żurek: "Gorgonowa i inni", KiW, Warszawa 1973 * Stanisław Milewski "Ciemne sprawy międzywojnia", Wydawnictwo Iskry : Warszawa, 2002 / rec. Józef Gurgul - Problemy kryminalistyki 250/2005

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox Prime Minister | name = Shukri Mohammed Imhemed Ghanem | native_name = شكري محمد إمحمد غانم | native_name_lang = ar | image = Shukri Ghanem 2010.jpg | office = Minister of Oil | term_start = 1 March 2006 | term_end = 16 May 2011 | predecessor = [[Fathi Ben Shatwan]] | successor = Position abolished
| office2 = [[List of heads of government of Libya|Prime Minister of Libya]] | term_start2 = 14 June 2003 | term_end2 = 5 March 2006 | predecessor2 = [[Imbarek Shamekh]] | successor2 = [[Baghdadi Mahmudi]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1942|10|9|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Tripoli]], [[Italian Libya|Libya]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2012|04|29|1942|10|9}} | death_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | alma_mater = [[Garyounis University]]
[[Tufts University]] }} '''Shukri Mohammed Ghanem''' ({{lang-ar|شكري محمد إمحمد غانم}} October 1942 – 29 April 2012) was a [[Libya]]n politician who was the [[List of heads of government of Libya|General Secretary]] of the [[General People's Committee of Libya]] (prime minister) from June 2003 until March 2006 when, in the first major government re-shuffle in over a decade, he was replaced by his deputy, [[Baghdadi Mahmudi]]. Ghanem subsequently served as the Minister of Oil until 2011. On 29 April 2012, his body was found floating on the [[New Danube]], [[Vienna]].{{cite news|url=http://www.tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=8289|title=Former Libyan PM, Oil Exec Ghanem Dies in Austria|work=[[Tripoli Post]]|date=29 April 2012|accessdate=30 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120507061014/http://www.tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=8289|archivedate=7 May 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2012/04/201242918484367273.html|title=Ex-Libyan oil minister's body found in Danube|work=Al Jazeera|date=30 April 2012|accessdate=30 April 2012}} Early in the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]] he reportedly "fled",{{Cite news|title=Live blog|work=Al Jazeera|date =21 February 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/17/live-blog-libya|accessdate=21 February 2011}} but after the city of [[Ra's Lanuf]] was recaptured by pro-government forces, [[Associated Press|AP]] reported on 13 March that he asked [[Eni|Eni SpA]] for help with putting out a fire at the [[Ra's Lanuf Refinery]].[http://www.canadianbusiness.com/markets/market_news/article.jsp?content=D9LU9JB00 Libya oil minister seeks help from Italy's Eni in extinguishing fire at Ras Lanouf facility]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On 16 May, Al Arabiya and the NTC reported that Shukri Ghanem defected to [[Tunisia]]. The next day Tunisian security officials confirmed he had indeed defected into Tunisia.{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703421204576328542926545706?mod=asia_home|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal| first1=Richard|last1=Boudreaux|title=Oil Chief Leaves Libya As Regime Is Targeted|date=18 May 2011}} ==Early life and education== Ghanem was born in [[Tripoli]] on 9 October 1942. He studied economics at [[Garyounis University]] in [[Benghazi]] and graduated in 1963. He also held PhD in international economics from the [[Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy]] at [[Tufts University]] and Harvard University in 1975. ==Career== Ghanem was previously in charge of the [[OPEC]] secretariat, and was the Director of its Research Division. He served as Deputy Director and Director of Foreign Trade at the Ministry of Economy in Libya; was Director of Marketing of Libya's [[National Oil Corporation]] (NOC); was Director of Economic Affairs and Under Secretary and Chief Advisor at the Ministry of Petroleum in Libya. In 2003, Ghanem was appointed General Secretary of the General People's Committee or Prime Minister.{{cite news|title=Shukri Ghanem|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/9237196/Shukri-Ghanem.html|accessdate=8 February 2013|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=30 April 2012}} In March 2006, Ghanem was appointed Chairman of Libya's NOC. He tendered his resignation from NOC in August 2009 amidst probable disagreements within the Libyan government over the development of the oil sector. After defection to Vienna in 2011, he served as a consultant for a Vienna-based company until his death. ==Post Lockerbie bombing raproachment== [[Libya]] had been diplomatically isolated and subject to international sanctions since the November 1991 [[indictment]] of two Libyans for the bombing of [[Pan Am Flight 103]] on 21 December 1988 (the [[Lockerbie bombing]]). Following Ghanem's appointment as prime minister, Libya successfully sought re-entry into the international community and the lifting of sanctions. Ghanem was seen as the main spokesman and architect of this rapprochement, which included paying [[United States dollars|$]]2.16 billion compensation in August 2003 to the families of the 270 people who died in the bombing, and renouncing [[weapons of mass destruction]]. In February 2004, Ghanem was interviewed on the BBC Radio 4 ''Today'' program.{{cite news|last=Thomson|first=Mike|title=The Libyan Prime Minister|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/today/reports/misc/libya_20040224.shtml|accessdate=8 February 2013|newspaper=BBCRadio 4|date=February 2004}} He stirred controversy in the interview by repudiating Libya's responsibility both for the 1988 Lockerbie bombing and the 1984 murder of British [[woman police constable|WPC]] [[Yvonne Fletcher]] (who was shot and killed in April 1984 outside the Libyan Embassy in London). This incident led to the severing of UK/Libya diplomatic relations.
After the problems we [Libya] have been facing because of the sanctions, the loss of money, we thought that it was easier for us to buy peace and this is why we agreed a compensation," Ghanem said in the interview.
When asked whether the payment of compensation meant that Libya did not accept any guilt or responsibility, Ghanem replied:
I agree with that, and this is why I say we bought peace.
Under pressure from the [[United States]] and [[United Kingdom|Britain]], Ghanem's comments were quickly retracted by [[Gaddafi]]. It is unclear whether Shukri Ghanem's dismissal as prime minister in 2006 was a consequence of those controversial remarks he made two years earlier. ==Libyan civil war== On 16 May 2011, it was reported that Ghanem has defected from the [[Libyan Arab Jamahiriya|Gaddafi government]] and fled,{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/16/us-libya-oil-ghanem-idUSTRE74F7UT20110516|work=Reuters|title=Libya's top oil official has defected: TV reports|date=16 May 2011}} which was confirmed the next day by Tunisian security officials. On 8 April 2011, against the background of the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]], the US Treasury department announced sanctions against him.{{cite web|title=Increasing Pressure on the Qadhafi Regime|url=http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/tg1131.aspx|publisher=US Department of Treasury|accessdate=8 February 2013|date=4 August 2011}} In May 2011, he defected to [[Rome]] and then, [[Vienna]]. On 1 June 2011, Ghanem confirmed in Rome, that he had decided to join the Libyan opposition.{{cite news|url= http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/06/01/libya.unrest/index.html|title= Libyan oil minister defects, says he might join opposition|newspaper=[[CNN]]|accessdate=2 June 2011|date=1 June 2011}} He was mistrusted by the new Libyan government due to his close friendship with the Gaddafi family, and particularly [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]].{{cite news|last1=Mills|first1=Robin|title=Did Libya's former oil minister Ghanem know too much?|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/industry-insights/energy/did-libyas-former-oil-minister-ghanem-know-too-much|accessdate=16 February 2016|date=May 9, 2012}} Prior to his death, the interim Libyan government was preparing an [[Interpol]] arrest warrant against him, to investigate his mismanagement of oil production. At the same time, he was also wanted as a witness in the trial against Saif al-Islam Gaddafi.{{cite web|title=Hillary Clinton's Emails|url=http://graphics.wsj.com/hillary-clinton-email-documents/#/?docid=C05794685|website=The Wall Street Journal}}{{cite news|last1=Shields|first1=Michael|last2=Lawler|first2=Alex|title=Drowned Libya oil chief feared going home|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-libya-ghanem-vienna-idUSBRE84D08820120514|accessdate=16 February 2016|agency=Reuters|date=May 14, 2012}} ==Personal life== Ghanem was married and had three daughters and one son.{{cite web|title=Shukri Ghanem obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/08/shukri-ghanem|website=The Guardian|accessdate=23 April 2018}} ==Death== Ghanem then lived with his family in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]], where he had an apartment and where his daughters also lived.{{cite news|title=Obituary: Libya's Shukri Ghanem|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/04/20124292046588343.html|accessdate=8 February 2013|newspaper=Al Jazeera|date=30 April 2012}} Prior to his death, Ghanem had expressed concerns about the latest developments in Libya. Ghanem's body was found fully clothed floating at 5 AM instead of the reported 08:40 CEST on 29 April 2012 in a branch of the [[River Danube]] though there were no signs of violence.{{cite news|last=Vinter|first=Phil|title=Gaddafi's former oil minister found floating in river Danube|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2137148/Dead-body-Shukri-Ghanem-river-Danube.html#axzz2KLNcl29W|accessdate=8 February 2013|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=30 April 2012}} He was 69.{{cite news|last=Mostyn|first=Trevor|title=Shukri Ghanem obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/08/shukri-ghanem|accessdate=8 February 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 May 2012}} An Austrian foreign ministry official said the family initially told the ministry that Ghanem had died of a heart attack, which was later denied by police. A BBC report noted the cause of death was not clear and that police had ordered a post-mortem.{{cite news|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-17889660|title=Libya ex-Minister Shukri Ghanem dead in Danube River|accessdate=29 April 2012|date=29 April 2012}} Toxicology tests were still being undertaken after Ghanem's body had been released for burial. His body, in a coffin wrapped in a white flag, was returned to Tripoli and buried there at the beginning of May 2012.{{cite news|title=Body of Shukri Ghanem Brought Home for Burial, Investigation Continues|url=http://www.tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=8312|accessdate=8 February 2013|newspaper=The Tripoli Post|date=4 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120807111816/http://www.tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=8312|archivedate=7 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} ==See also== *[[General People's Committee of Libya]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/4777332.stm Libya's reforming premier sacked] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before = [[Mubarak Abdallah al-Shamikh]]}} {{s-ttl|title = [[List of heads of government of Libya|General Secretary of the General People's Committee of Libya]]|years=14 June 2003 – 5 March 2006}} {{s-aft|after = [[Baghdadi Mahmudi]]}} {{s-end}} {{LibyaPMs}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ghanem, Shukri}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:Libyan defectors]] [[Category:Prime Ministers of Libya]] [[Category:Oil ministers of Libya]] [[Category:The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy alumni]] [[Category:Arabs]] [[Category:People of the Libyan Civil War (2011)]] [[Category:Members of the General People's Committee of Libya]] [[Category:Libyan emigrants to Italy]] [[Category:Libyan expatriates in Austria]]

{{Infobox NFL biography | name = Terry Hoage | image = <!-- Only free-content images are allowed for depicting living people -- see [[WP:NONFREE]]. --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | number = 24, 34, 41, 27 | position = [[Safety (American football position)|Safety]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|4|11|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Ames, Iowa]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 2 | weight_lbs = 201 | high_school = [[Huntsville Independent School District#High school|Huntsville]] ([[Huntsville, Texas]]) | college = [[Georgia Bulldogs football|Georgia]] | draftyear = 1984 | draftround = 3 | draftpick = 68 | pastteams = * [[New Orleans Saints]] ({{NFL Year|1984}}–{{NFL Year|1985}}) * [[Philadelphia Eagles]] ({{NFL Year|1986}}–{{NFL Year|1990}}) * [[Washington Redskins]] ({{NFL Year|1991}}–{{NFL Year|1992}}) * [[San Francisco 49ers]] ({{NFL Year|1993}}) * [[Houston Oilers]] ({{NFL Year|1993}}) * [[Arizona Cardinals]] ({{NFL Year|1994}}–{{NFL Year|1996}}) | highlights = * Consensus [[All-American]] ([[1982 College Football All-America Team|1982]], [[1983 College Football All-America Team|1983]]) * [[Today's Top VIII Award|Top V Award]] (1984) * [[Florida–Georgia football rivalry#Florida–Georgia Hall of Fame|Florida–Georgia Hall of Fame]] | statseason = 1996 | statlabel1 = Games played | statvalue1 = 142 | statlabel2 = Games started | statvalue2 = 65 | statlabel3 = Tackles | statvalue3 = 578 | statlabel4 = Interceptions | statvalue4 = 21 | statlabel5 = Recovered fumbles | statvalue5 = 12 | statlabel6 = Quarterback sacks | statvalue6 = 7.0 | nfl = HOA138430 | pfr = HoagTe20 | CollegeHOF = 2056 }}
'''Terrell Lee "Terry" Hoage''' (born April 11, 1962) is a former American college and professional [[American football|football]] player who was a [[Safety (gridiron football position)|safety]] in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) for thirteen seasons during the 1980s and 1990s. Hoage played [[college football]] for the [[University of Georgia]], and was recognized as an [[All-American]]. He played professionally for the [[New Orleans Saints]], [[Philadelphia Eagles]], [[Washington Redskins]], [[San Francisco 49ers]], [[Houston Oilers]] and [[Arizona Cardinals]] of the NFL.
== Early years ==
Hoage was born in [[Ames, Iowa]]. He moved to Huntsville, Texas in 1968 and attended elementary, intermediate and high school in Huntsville. In junior high and high school he played Football, Basketball and ran track for five years and was a starter in football from his sophomore year through senior playing both ways, as quarterback and free safety. He was recognized on All Trinity Valley and All District for all three years. His academic standing was in the top five percent and took college prep courses all four years in high school. Although he was college material, only Georgia offered him football scholarship where became a starter in his sophomore year. Huntsville Independent School District 1976–1980.
== College career ==
Hoage attended the University of Georgia, where he played for coach [[Vince Dooley]]'s [[Georgia Bulldogs football]] team from 1980 to 1983. As a junior and again as a senior, was a recognized as a consensus first [[All-American]]. Coach Dooley called Hoage "the best defensive player I've ever coached and maybe the best one I've ever seen."<ref>[http://www.cosida.com/news.asp?id=440 Academic All-America Hall of Fame Class Inducted]</ref> He finished fifth in the voting for the [[Heisman Trophy]] in 1983.<ref>[http://www.heisman.com/winners/m-rozier83.html 1983 Heisman Trophy voting] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061030194828/http://www.heisman.com/winners/m-rozier83.html |date=2006-10-30 }}</ref> He graduated from Georgia in 1985 with a [[bachelor's degree]] in genetics with a 3.85 grade point average. Terry's college roommate, [[Mike Hubbard (politician)|Mike Hubbard]], became the first Republican Speaker of the Alabama House of Representatives in 136 years.
== Professional career ==
Hoage was selected by the [[New Orleans Saints]] in the third round (sixty-eight pick overall) of the [[1984 NFL Draft]].<ref>[http://www.nfl.com/draft/history/schools/GA Draft history for UGA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061111203052/http://www.nfl.com/draft/history/schools/GA |date=2006-11-11 }}</ref> His NFL career spanned 13 seasons and six teams: the New Orleans Saints, [[Philadelphia Eagles]], [[Washington Redskins]], [[Houston Oilers]], [[San Francisco 49ers]] and [[Arizona Cardinals]]. His professional football career ended in 1996. Hoage scored his only NFL touchdown in the first game of the 1988 season when he rushed for a 38-yard touchdown against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.<ref>{{cite news |last=Frank |first= Reuben|date=September 6, 2018|title=Roob's 10 observations: Nick Foles' strange career, Jason Peters' age, 2018 predictions |url=https://www.nbcsports.com/philadelphia/eagles/roobs-10-observations-nick-foles-strange-career-jason-peters-age-2018-predictions-repeat-super-bowl-nfl |work=CSNPhilly |location=Philadelphia |access-date= }}</ref>
== Life after football == After retiring from football, Hoage interned at [[Merrill Lynch]], passed the [[Series 7 exam]], and seemed on his way to a career in finance. However, as he would recall in a 2012 interview, "I absolutely hated it. The coat and tie. Going to the office. It didn't fit my personality at all." He and his wife Jennifer, along with their two children, then moved to [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], where he started a construction company, but were still not satisfied with their family life. They then moved to [[Templeton, California]], a small [[Central Coast (California)|Central Coast]] town. He had one further opportunity to become involved in the game, but turned down [[Jeff Fisher]]'s offer of a coaching position with the [[Tennessee Titans]]. Hoage then began farming a small piece of land in the area.<ref name=Watson>{{cite web|url=http://www.thepostgame.com/blog/chompions/201203/former-georgia-great-terry-hoage-wins-losing-game-wine-making |title=Former Georgia Great Terry Hoage Wins At The Losing Game Of Wine Making |first=Adam |last=Watson |work=The Post Game |publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]] |date=March 8, 2012 |accessdate=April 7, 2012}}</ref>
In 2002, the Hoages discovered a {{convert|26|acre|m2|adj=on}} vineyard in [[Paso Robles, California]] that had just come on the market. Terry called in Justin Smith, a friend and winemaker who would go on to produce a wine named by ''[[Wine Spectator]]'' as Wine of the Year, to evaluate the land. [[Yahoo! Sports]] writer Adam Watson said that Hoage's involvement with Smith was "the equivalent of shopping for a computer with a young Bill Gates." When Smith indicated that the property had world-class potential, the Hoages bought the property, moved onto it, and enlisted Smith to help them get started in the business. The association with Smith gave the Hoages credibility as they started their business, and they took over the winemaking in 2004.<ref name=Watson />
They were named among the Top New California Wine Producers in 2008 by ''Wine Spectator''. The vineyard is operated as '''Terry Hoage Vineyards''' and produces Rhone varietal wines.<ref>[http://www.terryhoagevineyards.com/ Terry Hoage Vineyards]</ref> Hoage produces roughly 2,000 cases a year. The vineyard's first wine was The Hedge a Syrah. The "Hedge" refers both to a pruning technique and the fabled Hedges of the University of Georgia's [[Sanford Stadium]].<ref>Sports Illustrated, July 2, 2007, p. 86</ref> Hoage dedicated his first vintage of The Hedge to his former coach, Vince Dooley. Hoage's later wines have been marketed with names of a similar concept, playing off both his football and winemaking careers. "46" refers to the [[46 defense]] created by [[Buddy Ryan]], for whom Hoage played eight seasons, and [[California State Route 46|Highway 46]], that runs into Paso Robles. "Skins" refers both to the Redskins and grape skins. "5 Blocks" comes from Hoage's five blocked field goals at Georgia, plus the specific area of grapes used.<ref name=Watson />
== Awards and honors ==
* Two-time consensus first-team All-American * Two-time [[Southeastern Conference|SEC]] Defensive Player of the Year * 5th in voting for the 1983 [[Heisman Trophy]]<ref>http://www.mikehubbard.com</ref> * [[1984 Top V Award]] * 1984 SEC Athlete of the Year Award<ref>[http://www.secsports.com/index.php?url_channel_id=4&url_article_id=7470&url_subchannel_id=&change_well_id=2 Carter, Augustus Named SEC Athletes of the Year] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930160347/http://www.secsports.com/index.php?url_channel_id=4&url_article_id=7470&url_subchannel_id=&change_well_id=2 |date=2007-09-30 }}</ref> * 1997 Georgia-Florida Hall of Fame<ref>[http://www.coj.net/Departments/Parks+and+Recreation/Special+Events/FlaGa/EVENTS/Hall+of+Fame+Induction+Ceremony.htm Georgia-Florida Hall of Fame]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> * 2000 inductee in the [[College Football Hall of Fame]] * 2004 inductee in the CoSIDA Academic Hall of Fame * 2009 inductee in the Georgia Sports Hall of Fame * Named to the [[Southeastern Conference|SEC]] 25-year team (1961–85). * Named to Walter Camp All Century Team as a safety<ref>[http://www.waltercamp.org/allcentury5.htm Walter Camp All Century Team] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060909034904/http://www.waltercamp.org/allcentury5.htm |date=2006-09-09 }}</ref>

武磊 | image = Wu Lei.jpg | fullname = Wu Lei | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1991|11|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], China | height = {{height|m=1.74}}{{cite web|title=Wu Lei|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/lei-wu/116426/|website=Soccerway|accessdate=31 July 2016}} | position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Right winger]] | currentclub = [[Shanghai SIPG F.C.|Shanghai SIPG]] | clubnumber = 7 | youthyears1 = 2003–2005 | youthclubs1 = [[Genbao Football Academy]] | years1 = 2006– | clubs1 = [[Shanghai SIPG F.C.|Shanghai SIPG]] | caps1 = 296 | goals1 = 151 | nationalyears1 = 2007–2008 | nationalteam1 = [[China national under-17 football team|China U-17]] | nationalcaps1 = 8 | nationalgoals1 = 7 | nationalyears2 = 2009–2010 | nationalteam2 = [[China national under-20 football team|China U-20]] | nationalcaps2 = 9 | nationalgoals2 = 11 | nationalyears3 = 2010– | nationalteam3 = [[China national football team|China]] | nationalcaps3 = 57 | nationalgoals3 = 12 | pcupdate = 20 November 2018 | ntupdate = 20 November 2018 }} {{Infobox Chinese |c={{linktext|武|磊}} |p=Wǔ Lěi |mi={{IPAc-cmn|wu|3|-|l|ei|3|}} }} '''Wu Lei''' ({{zh|s=武磊|p=Wǔ Lěi}}; born 19 November 1991) is a [[Chinese people|Chinese]] footballer who currently plays for [[Shanghai SIPG F.C.|Shanghai SIPG]] in the [[Chinese Super League]]. He is currently the all-time top goalscorer for the club with 169 goals and has also made the most appearances for the club. He currently holds the record for being the youngest person to have played in a professional Chinese football match aged just 14 years and 287 days. ==Club career== Wu Lei started his football career playing for third-tier side [[Shanghai SIPG F.C.|Shanghai SIPG]], making his debut for the club on 2 September 2006 in a 5–3 loss against [[Yunnan Lijiang Dongba]], making him the youngest ever player to play professional Chinese football aged 14 years and 287 days.[http://sports.sina.com.cn/c/2006-09-03/01022434734.shtml 乙级也有上海德比：武磊上场创纪录 东亚遗憾负东巴] at sports.sina.com.cn 2006-09-03 Retrieved 2012-09-08 He helped the club win the third tier title and promotion to the second tier at the end of the 2007 league season. He scored his first goal for the club on 30 August 2008 in a 2–0 win against [[Qingdao Hailifeng]]. This made him the second youngest goalscorer in Chinese football aged 16 years and 289 days, just 47 days behind [[Cao Yunding]]'s record.[http://sports.qq.com/a/20080902/000437.htm 东亚小将刷新联赛纪录 中国马拉多纳前途无量] at sports.qq.com 2008-09-02 Retrieved 2012-09-08 Wu scored a hat trick on 2 June 2013 in a 6–1 win against [[Shanghai Shenxin F.C.|Shanghai Shenxin]], becoming the second youngest player to score a hat-trick in the top tier.[http://sports.163.com/13/0603/14/90F0B7NP00051C89.html 上海德比爆大冷 武磊成中超最年轻帽子戏法球员] at sports.163.com 2013-06-03 Retrieved 2013-06-04 He scored his second hat-trick of the season on 18 August 2013 in a 3–2 win against [[Tianjin Teda F.C.|Tianjin Teda]]. He scored his third hat trick of the season on 27 September 2013 in a 6–1 win against [[Qingdao Jonoon]]. On 31 July 2016, Wu became the first Chinese footballer in over two years to score a hat-trick in the [[Chinese Super League]] in a 3–3 draw against [[Guangzhou R&F F.C.|Guangzhou R&F]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.shanghaidaily.com/sports/soccer/Wus-hattrick-salvages-point-for-SIPG/shdaily.shtml |title=Wu’s hat-trick salvages point for SIPG|publisher=Shanghai Daily |date=31 July 2016}}[http://sports.sohu.com/20140330/n397452709.shtml 杜震宇戴帽泰达3–0获首胜 毅腾遭四连败] {{zh icon}} ==International career== Wu was called up to the [[China national under-20 football team|Chinese under-20 national team]] in 2009 and scored nine goals in five matches during the [[2010 AFC U-19 Championship qualification|2010 AFC U-19 Championship]]qualification matches.[http://news.xinmin.cn/rollnews/2009/11/12/2903147.html 亚足联盛赞国青惊艳表现 称宿家军表现能得满分] at news.xinmin.cn 2009-11-12 Retrieved 2012-09-08 His impressive goalscoring performances saw him called up to the [[China national football team|Chinese national team]] for the [[2010 East Asian Football Championship]], making his debut on 14 February 2010 in a 2–0 win against [[Hong Kong national football team|Hong Kong]].[http://www.eaff.com/competitions/eafc2010/results/20100214_M5_HKGvsCHN_E.pdf Score Sheet(PDF) – EAFF : EAST ASIAN FOOTBALL FEDERATION] at eaff.com February 14, 2010 Retrieved 2012-09-08 Several months later, Wu returned to the under-20 national team for the [[2010 AFC U-19 Championship]] and he played in four games and score two goals while he aided China to the quarterfinals by the end of the tournament. He scored his first goal for China on 28 July 2013 in a 4–3 win against [[Australia national football team|Australia]] at the [[2013 EAFF East Asian Cup]]. ==Career statistics== ===Club statistics=== {{updated|11 November 2018}} [http://www.sodasoccer.com/search/player/86/171475/E0B52309452810ED.shtml 武磊] at sodasoccer.com.
